title: Support real-time programming
body:
It'd be awesome to (eventually) support real-time programming in Rust, enabling real-time programmers to move off the error-prone C/C++ languages.

("Real-time" means predictably meeting time deadlines, e.g. in avionics, video capture, medical x-ray, and robotics. Speed is important but the crucial point is reliably meeting deadlines. Garbage collectors, JIT compilers, and run-time optimizers are bad for predictability, so Java's RTSJ has inherent problems in addition to its complexity.)

Many real-time programs are also safety-critical, which entails more or less the same language needs as security-critical programming: fewer failure modes, easy to understand and reason about, less error-prone, easy to learn, easy to document.

Rust is a great base for this. AIUI, the remaining pieces are:
- [ ] A run-time library (or a special profile of the standard library) that can fork real-time tasks as native threads (that don't cooperatively share threads via N:M concurrency) and that explicitly omits GC managed memory facilities. This will require expertise in low-level Rust core libraries.
- [ ] Instructions on using this library, including using `#[deny(managed_heap_memory)]` and `#[no_std]` et al to ensure the code can't directly or indirectly use GC managed memory.
- [x] Meanwhile, don't rule-out real-time programs, e.g. don't let a garbage collector pause a ~~thread~~ Rust task that doesn't use GC managed memory.

Ideally, code outside the real-time tasks would be able to use GC managed memory, say in parsing command-line arguments, but that's not required.
